 I. 

BACKGROUND 

The grant to the Republic of the Marshall Islands for the Energy Security Project will be 

 
1. 
On 22 June 2017, the Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved 
the  Pacific  Renewable  Energy  Investment  Facility.1  The  facility  will  finance  renewable  energy 
projects in 11 Pacific developing member countries with an overall estimated cost of $750 million, 
including ADB financing of up to $200 million. Upon approval, the Board delegated authority to 
the President to approve loans and/or grants to each targeted country for qualifying projects. 
 
2. 
financed under the facility. 
 
3. 
The  project  will  rehabilitate  the  Majuro  tank  farm  (MTF),  the  fuel  handling  and  storage 
facilities built in 1981 and operated by Marshalls Energy Company (MEC) on Majuro Atoll. The 
MTF  comprises  eight  750,000-gallon  (2.84  million-liter)  above-ground  steel  storage tanks,  two 
smaller  intermediate  transfer  tanks,  and  associated  piping  and  pumping  infrastructure.  Power 
generation throughout the Marshall Islands is dependent on fuel delivered by MEC through the 
MTF, as is domestic and international maritime transport operating in  Marshall Islands waters. 
The  MTF  has  become  dilapidated  because  of  the  harsh  operating  environment  and  chronic 
inadequate maintenance practices and budgeting. The project will return the MTF to compliance 
with  applicable  industry  standards  and  will  institute  policies  and  operating  practices  (including 
personnel training) to provide for appropriate maintenance to ensure its sustainability. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
4. 
Macroeconomic  context.  The  Marshall  Islands  is  heavily  dependent  on  external 
assistance, with annual grants averaging 60% of gross domestic product (GDP), mostly through 
the  Compact  of  Free  Association  (COFA)  with  the  United  States,  which  terminates  in  2023. 
Unemployment is high and human development indicators are generally low; income distribution 
is quite uneven and poverty on the outer atolls is considerable. When grant flows from the COFA 
declined  during  1995–2001,  per  capita  GDP  over  the  same  period  dropped  by  nearly  35%. 
Economic  growth  accelerated  from  0.6%  in  FY2015  to  1.5%  in  FY2016  because  of  stronger 
fisheries  output  and  the  resumption  of  infrastructure  projects  connected  with  the  COFA.  ADB 
estimates growth of 4.0% in FY2017 and forecasts 2.5% in FY2018,2 and an economic review 
prepared through Graduate School USA expects average GDP growth of 1.7% through FY2025.3 
 
5. 
Renewable energy investment demand. MEC is a fully state-owned electricity utility that 
generates, distributes, and retails electricity on Majuro to a population of about 28,000 (roughly 
half of the Marshall Islands’ population). Serving the country’s capital, the Majuro system accounts 
for 72% of electricity generated and consumed in the Marshall Islands. Ebeye in Kwajalein Atoll 
accounts for an additional 24%, while the outer islands make up the balance. Renewable power 
generation in the Marshall Islands is negligible; nearly all power delivered to customers on Majuro 
is  generated  from  diesel  fuel.  While  the  Government  of  the  Marshall  Islands  has  established 
ambitious  greenhouse  gas  emissions  reduction  and  renewable  energy  targets  based  on  its 
nationally determined contributions (NDCs) under the Paris Agreement (implying a required 50% 
                                                
1  ADB. 2017. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Facility for the Pacific 

Renewable Energy Investment Facility. Manila. 

2  ADB. 2017. Asian Development Outlook 2017: Transcending the Middle-Income Challenge. Manila. 
3  M. Sturton and G. McKinlay. 2016. Republic of the Marshall Islands: Fiscal Year 2015 Economic Review—October, 

2016. Honolulu: Graduate School USA Pacific Islands Training Initiative. 

 

 

 reduction  in  diesel  consumption  for  power  generation  by  2025),4  achieving  these  targets  will 
require  an  investment  of  at  least  $120  million.5  Funding  for  these  investments  has  not  been 
identified. Responsible sector investment planning demands that existing plant and infrastructure, 
including the MTF, be maintained and preserved until they become obsolete and are replaced by 
alternative plants and technologies. 
 
6. 
Urgency of tank farm rehabilitation. The MTF was commissioned in 1981 and appears 
to  have  been  designed  and  soundly  constructed  in  compliance  with  applicable  codes  and 
standards.  However,  its  current  condition  is  very  poor—a  consequence  of  many  years  of 
inadequate  maintenance  in  a  harsh  and  corrosive  marine  environment  that  is  subject  to 
atmospheric  salt  spray  from  all  directions.  All  tanks  and  above-ground  piping  show  significant 
signs of corrosion. The concrete bunding also exhibits deterioration. Concrete flooring under tanks 
has eroded significantly, exacerbating corrosion and causing stress on the steel tanks’ welding 
joints. Critical safety and security features, such as ladders, bannisters, and basic lighting, have 
also deteriorated or are entirely absent. 
 
The MTF is a critical facility and the cornerstone of the Marshall Islands’ energy security. 
7. 
Its dilapidated and rapidly deteriorating condition is a severe risk to the Marshall Islands economy, 
the population’s well-being, and the local environment. The risk of catastrophic failure of the tanks 
and  associated  infrastructure  (pumping  equipment,  piping,  and  containment  bunding)  is 
significant.  Such  failure  will  likely  result  in  an  acute  and  prolonged  shortage  of  fuel  for  power 
generation,  a  significant  adverse  environmental  impact,  and  extraordinarily  high  costs  for 
remediation and interim alternative supply of fuel, as well as loss of revenue for MEC from fuel 
sales to commercial marine fleets. 
 
8. 
Rehabilitation  of  the  MTF  will  preserve  the  Marshall  Islands’  energy  security,  while 
mitigating  risks  associated  with potential  catastrophic failure.  MEC’s  fuel  supply  to commercial 
maritime  transport  and  fishing  fleets  also  contributes  significantly  to  the  Marshall  Islands’ 
economy  and  is  a  revenue  source  for  MEC  that  helps  support  its  other  operations  (power 
generation and sales). 
 
9. 
Value added by ADB assistance. Through technical assistance (TA), ADB is supporting 
MEC in its reforms to ensure its future as a viable and sustainable commercial public enterprise.6 
The rehabilitation of the MTF under the project will take place while the reform measures that this 
TA is preparing are being implemented. ADB is also implementing a grant to the Marshall Islands 
for improving the power network distribution in Majuro,7 and considering a waste-to-energy project 
that will contribute to the Marshall Islands’ renewable energy targets and an additional network 
strengthening investment project. Implementation of the reform measures that will be developed 
under the TA will form part of the planned future investments. 
 
Development coordination. The project will be implemented alongside investments and 
10. 
technical  assistance  supported  by  other  development  partners,  including  the  World  Bank,  the 
European Union, Japanese International Cooperation Agency, the Government of New Zealand, 

                                                
4  In its NDCs, the Marshall Islands set a target of a 45% reduction of greenhouse gas emissions based on 2010 levels 

5  Government of the Marshall Islands. Forthcoming. Navigating our Energy Future: Marshall Islands Electricity Road

by 2030.

Pacific. Manila (TA 9425-REG). 

7  ADB.  2017.  Pacific  Renewable  Energy  Investment  Facility:  Majuro  Power  Network  Strengthening  Project  in  the 

Republic of the Marshall Islands. Manila (G0554-RMI). 

2 

 

 and the Abu Dhabi Fund for Development.  These development partners’ investments are focused 
primarily  on  expansion  of  the  Marshall  Islands’  solar  power  generation.  The  World  Bank, 
European Union, and the Government of New Zealand are also providing technical assistance for 
policy development, sector planning (footnote 5), and capacity-building as a complement to their 
capital investments.   
 
11. 
Alignment with development plans. The project is included in ADB’s country operations 
business plan, 2019–2021 for the Marshall Islands8. It also supports the country’s National Energy 
Policy and Energy Action Plan9 and is aligned with the National Strategic Plan 2015-2017 (still 
current), which prioritizes the rehabilitation of the MTF.10 The country operations business plan 
also envisages further investments in MEC (para. 9). The project is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
2030 (Table 1).11 
 

Table 1: Alignment with ADB’s Strategy 2030 
Project’s Contributions 
Generating quality jobs. Energy is a key factor of production and essential 
for economic activity. Preserving Marshall Island’s energy security is vital 
for reducing poverty. 
(i)  Supporting public management reforms and financial stability. The 
project will contribute to improvements in the corporate governance 
and financial management practices of MEC, which may catalyze 
similar improvements in the public sector (other state-owned 
enterprises).  

(ii)  Strengthening service delivery. The project will address the long-term 
viability of MEC, including through tariff-related reforms and financial 
management improvements. 

Scaling up support to address climate change, disaster risks, and 
environmental degradation. The project will increase the climate resiliency 
of the MTF and make it less vulnerable to extreme weather, coastal 
erosion, and flooding. 

Strategy 2030 Priority 
1.  Addressing remaining 
poverty and reducing 
inequalities

governance and 
institutional capacity

change, building

resilience, and 
enhancing 
environmental 
sustainability

Source: Asian Development Bank. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable 
Asia and the Pacific. Manila. 
 
12. 
Notwithstanding  that  the  MTF’s  dilapidated  and  deteriorating  condition  has  been  well-
documented and understood by stakeholders for some time,12 no development-partner support 
has been pledged to address the urgent investment needed to rehabilitate the MTF. Irrespective 
of the Marshall Islands’ and development partners’ prioritization of increased power generation 
from renewable sources (where the bulk of assistance resources have been directed in the past 
several years), the Marshall Islands will continue to rely on diesel as the cornerstone of its energy 

                                                
8  ADB. 2016. Country Operations Business Plan: Marshall Islands, 2017–2019. Manila. 
9    Government of  the  Marshall  Islands,  Ministry of  Resources  and  Development.  2016.  National  Energy  Policy  and 

Energy Action Plan. Majuro. 

10 Government of the Marshall Islands. 2014. National Strategic Plan. Majuro. 
11 ADB.  2018.  Strategy  2030:  Achieving  a  Prosperous,  Inclusive,  Resilient,  and  Sustainable  Asia  and  the  Pacific. 

12 The World Bank funded a Micronesia Tank Farm Integrity Survey in 2011 that reported significant uncontrolled risks 

Manila. 

at the MTF. 

3 

 

 security for several decades (even if it is fully successful in achieving its nationally determined 
contributions (NDCs) under the 2015 UNFCCC Paris Agreement13). 
 
13. 
The project is included under the Pacific Renewable Energy Investment Facility (footnote 
1), which aims to improve regional energy security in the Pacific region. The facility was approved 
to cover supporting infrastructure, including required power sector infrastructure to maintain grid 
operation.  This  includes,  but  is  not  limited  to,  transmission  and  distribution  assets,  diesel 
generation  rehabilitation  and  upgrades,  and  rehabilitation  of  tank  farm  assets.14  The  project 
qualifies to be approved under the Pacific Renewable Energy Financing Facility because (i) the 
project’s scope includes renewable energy generation and supporting energy sector infrastructure 
(para. 14), (ii) the Marshall Islands is one of the 11 eligible Pacific developing member countries, 
(iii) the project is identified in national energy sector planning documents as a priority investment 
(footnote 10), and (iv) the project has been classified category B for environment.  
 
14. 
Preservation of, and reinvestment in, MEC’s and Kwajalein Atoll Joint Utilities Resources’ 
(KAJUR)  existing  diesel  generation  assets  will  remain  cost-effective  and necessary  under  any 
realistic  scenario,  even  if  RMI  achieves  its  renewable  energy  targets:  intermittent  renewable 
energy resources, irrespective of the extent of installation of capital-intensive battery storage and 
other enabling technologies, cannot cost-effectively form the basis of a reliable power grid in the 
Marshall  Islands  context.    This  can  only  be  provided  by  diesel  generation  in  this  context.  
Intermittent renewable generation technologies can cost-effectively only complement and partially 
displace diesel generation; they cannot replace it.  In fact, dispatch of any amount of intermittent 
renewable power generation in RMI’s power systems (MEC and KAJUR) is not feasible without 
diesel generation forming the basis of the power systems to maintain system frequency. 
 
B. 
 
15. 
The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) energy security for the Marshall Islands 
improved and (ii) safety and environmental risks associated with handling and storage of refined 
petroleum  products  reduced.15  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  safe  and  reliable 
operation  of  the  fuel  tank  farm  sustained  and  supply  of  fuel  to  power  generation  facilities 
throughout the Marshall Islands continued.16 
 
C. 
 
16. 
Output  1:  Majuro  tank  farm  rehabilitated.  The  project  will  fund  an  engineering, 
procurement,  and  construction  contract  for  (i)  the  restoration  of  all  fuel  tank  farm  facilities  to 
acceptable condition for sustained operation in compliance with applicable norms and standards 
for safety, reliability, and environmental protection; and (ii) repair and enhancement of the seawall 
that protects the MTF from erosion and storm surge (the MTF boundary is within 20 meters of the 
ocean side of the atoll). 
 
17. 
Output  2:  Majuro  tank  farm  operation  and  maintenance  program  instituted.  The 
project  will  develop  adequate  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  procedures  and  practices, 
including  the  identification  of  budgeting  requirements,  to  ensure  sustained  operation  of  the

rehabilitated facilities. MEC personnel will be trained to implement these procedures and practices 
throughout project implementation. 
 
D. 
 
18. 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $16.8  million  (Table  2).  Detailed  cost  estimates  by 
expenditure category and by financier are included in the project administration manual (PAM).17

19. 
The government has requested a grant not exceeding $12.7 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources (Asian Development  Fund [ADF])  to  help finance  the  project. The  Ministry  of 
Finance (MOF) will provide the funds to MEC under a subsidiary grant agreement. 
 
20. 
The summary financing plan is in Table 3. ADB will finance the expenditures in relation to 
site preparation, seawall repair and construction, works and goods for rehabilitation of the main 
tank farm facilities, and consulting services and training. The government has agreed to provide 
counterpart financing for costs in excess of the available ADF grant resources, exemption of taxes 
and duties, and contingencies. MEC will provide counterpart support for site preparation in the 
form of unskilled labor.

E. 
 
21. 
The MOF will be the executing agency and MEC will be the implementing agency. ADB 
and the government have agreed to form a project steering committee, which will be led by the 
chair  of  the  Combined  Utilities  Board  and  will  comprise  the  director  of  the  MOF’s  Division  of 
International Development Assistance, the national energy planner of the Ministry of Resources

coordination officer. The MEC chief executive officer and chief technical officer will be supported 
by consultants to be appointed under the project to manage implementation.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
23. 
The rehabilitation of the fuel tank farm facility has been assessed as technically viable. 
The MTF is the largest fuel storage in the Central Pacific. It is used to store fuel for electricity 
generation  throughout  the  Marshall  Islands,  as  well  as  for  the  supply  of  the  international  and 
domestic fishing industry, international and domestic marine transport, and local road transport. 
 
24. 
The  fuel  tank  farm  facility’s  rehabilitation  is  an  urgent  priority.  Its  dilapidated  condition 
presents multiple risks. Catastrophic failure of its critical components could lead to the facility’s 
inability  to  provide  fuel  handling  and  storage  services.  The  health  and  welfare  of  personnel 
employed in fuel handling and storage operations are in jeopardy because of the facility’s poor 
condition, lack of safety equipment, and poor operational practices. The risk of an adverse local 
environmental impact if critical component failure leads to large-volume spillage of diesel fuel or 
waste oil currently stockpiled at the facility is also significant. 
 
25. 
The fuel tank farm facility is adjacent to the ocean side (south side) of the Majuro lagoon, 
and is protected from erosion and inundation by a sloping rock seawall. The seawall has subsided 
in some  places,  and waves occasionally  overtop  the  seawall  and deposit  debris  in the facility. 
Since  1988,  three recorded  high-water  events  have  inundated  part  of  the site. While  the  bund 
around the fuel storage tanks has not been breached, inundation remains a real risk given the 

6 

 

 Economic and Financial 

The project will need to be implemented in stages to allow for uninterrupted operation of 

anticipated  sea-level  rise  and  extreme  weather  event  intensification  from  climate  change. 
Accordingly, the project will  include rehabilitation and enhancement of the rock seawall on the 
south side of the facility to mitigate against climate change-related risks. 
 
The rehabilitation and upgrade of the MTF will include the replacement of tank assets and 
26. 
equipment that will be permanently exposed to the elements over their life cycle. The tank farm 
facility  technical  due  diligence  for  rehabilitation  has  been  conducted  following  the  American 
Petroleum  Institution  standard  653  (API  653),  which  provides  minimum  requirements  for 
maintaining the integrity of such facilities after they have been placed in service; and addresses 
inspection, repair, alteration, relocation, and reconstruction. Works and goods packages under 
the project will be based on this and other applicable standards. 
 
The  project  will  include  advisory  services  for  the  development,  implementation,  and 
27. 
incorporation into MEC’s routine business operations of appropriate arrangements and practices 
for the O&M of the rehabilitated fuel tank farm facility. This will include training MEC personnel 
and allocating sufficient budget for continuous and adequate O&M program implementation. 
 
28. 
the MTF facilities, hence the implementation period from 2019 through 2023. 
 
B. 
 
29. 
The project is found to be economically viable, with an economic internal rate of return 
(EIRR)  of  16.9%,  above  the  9.0%  minimum  required  EIRR  for  ADB  investment  projects,  and 
economic net present value of $10.8 million.  This is due mainly to the substantial benefits arising 
from  the  uninterrupted  operation  and  extended  economic  life  of  the  MTF,  which  would  also 
facilitate continued sale of fuel for power generation, as well as for maritime transport.  Economic 
viability is most sensitive to reductions in benefits, although sensitivity analyses confirm that the 
project is expected to remain viable across a range of adverse scenarios. 
 
30. 
The FIRR for the project is 4% and the FNPV, when discounted at the WACC of 1.8%, is 
$2.4  million.  This  demonstrates  that  the  project  is  financially  viable  to  its  owner,  MEC.  
Refurbishment of the MTF would facilitate the uninterrupted sale of fuel, resulting in large annual 
revenue streams. Financial viability likewise remains robust across adverse project scenarios. 
 
C. 
 
31. 
ADB conducted a financial management assessment for the implementing agency, MEC. 
Inherent financial management risk of the project before mitigation was assessed as substantial 
because  of  MEC’s  entity-level  risks18.  MEC  has  delegated  the  selection  of  the  project 
implementation consultants to ADB. Contractors and consultants will be paid directly by ADB. 
 
32. 
To  address  threats  to  MEC’s  long-term  viability,  the  MOF  and  MEC  have  agreed  to 
implement reform measures that are being prepared under ADB technical assistance (footnote 
6). These reform measures will be presented to MEC and the government in the second quarter 
of 2019.  In advance of this, the government has assented to four key assurances in the project 
legal agreements:  
 

Governance 

                                                
18 MEC Financial Management Assessment and Financial Analysis of MEC (accessible from the list of linked documents 

in Appendix 2). 

7 

 

 (i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

within  1  year  of  grant  effectiveness,  the  government  has  committed  to  transfer 
ownership of the MTF to MEC; 
within 15 months of grant effectiveness, the government has committed to a reform 
of  MEC’s  corporate  governance  arrangements  such  that  they  conform  to 
Organization  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development’s  Guidelines  for 
Corporate Governance of State-Owned Enterprises (2015); 
the government  will  provide for  a  tariff  policy  and  rate  structure  that establishes 
MEC’s  authorized  revenue  based  on  verifiable,  prudent  and  reasonable  costs, 
while providing MEC an opportunity to recover its costs associated with providing 
electricity service and incentivizing MEC to control and minimize its costs; and 
the government will cause MEC to make available adequate budgetary resources 
for the implementation of a suitable O&M program for the MTF (Output 2 of the 
project). 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

 
33. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, the MOF and MEC. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual19. 
 
D. 
 
The  project  will  provide  sustainability  of  critical  economic  infrastructure  in  the  Marshall 
34. 
Islands that is at risk of catastrophic failure.  Such failure would have a severe negative impact 
on the Marshall Islands economy, and on the population’s well-being and societal welfare.  This 
project is an urgent necessity to prevent such failure. 
 
35. 
The project is classified no gender elements given the limited scope to ensure realistic 
and safe gender mainstreaming in the rehabilitation works. However, the project includes some 
proactive  gender  features  including  (i)  ensuring  women  are  involved  in  operation  and 
maintenance training and (ii) ensuring the project management unit (PMU) conducts training as 
required to increase gender awareness among MEC staff and the contractors. ADB will provide 
training  to the  PMU  and project staff  on the  principles outlined in the  multilateral  development 
banks’ joint statement on combatting sexual exploitation to ensure that the PMU and project staff 
are  able  to  detect,  intercept,  respond  to,  and  prevent  (or  refer)  cases  of  sexual  harassment, 
gender-based violence, and other problems that may emerge during project implementation. In 
addition, the project will indirectly support women through the continued provision of basic energy 
services  that  provide  specific  benefits  to  women  including  increased  safety,  increased 
opportunities for women’s economic empowerment, and time saved from sourcing alternative fuel 
sources. 
 
E. 
 
36. 
categories are as follows.20 
 
Environment (category B). An initial environmental examination was prepared following 
37. 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. The project is expected to have only small, temporary, and 
localized adverse impacts on the environment, which can be readily managed by the proposed 

In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  project’s  safeguard

38. 
The  project  includes  a  comprehensive  and  detailed  environmental  management  plan, 
whose implementation will be incorporated into the goods and works packages and consulting 
services for project implementation supervision support. The project will also institute adequate 
O&M procedures for the rehabilitated tank farm facility, including environmental monitoring and 
risk-abatement measures. MEC personnel will be trained to implement these O&M procedures. 
 
39. 
Involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  (category  C).  The  due  diligence 
report confirmed that the project will not require any land acquisition, displace people, or have an 
impact  on  any  assets  or  livelihoods.  No  distinct  and  vulnerable  indigenous  peoples  will  be 
affected.  All  activities  in the  overall  project  will  be  implemented  in  a  culturally  appropriate  and 
participatory manner.

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

 
41. 
The government, the MOF, and MEC have assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and grant documents.

V. 

THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 

 
43. 
The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board through the approval of 
the  Pacific  Renewable  Energy  Investment  Facility,  has  approved  the  grant  not  exceeding 
$12,700,000 to the Republic of the Marshall Islands, from ADB’s Special Funds resources (Asian 
Development  Fund),  for  the  Energy  Security  Project,  on  terms  and  conditions  that  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant and project agreements.
